urn:contentItem:6GD4-XT03-RTH6-B23R-00000-00New Climatology Findings Has Been Reported by Investigators at University of Alaska Fairbanks (On Using Dynamical Seasonal Forecasts To Develop Management-driven Wildland Fire Outlooks In Alaska)2025-08-01T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:00:08ZLexisNexisSCIENCE - CLIMATOLOGYNew Climatology Findings Has Been Reported by Investigators at University of Alaska Fairbanks (On Using Dynamical Seasonal Forecasts To Develop Management-driven Wildland Fire Outlooks In Alaska)


2025 JUL 01 (NewsRx) -- By a News Reporter-Staff News Editor at NewsRx Science Daily -- Researchers detail new data in Science - Climatology. According to news originating from Fairbanks, Alaska, by NewsRx correspondents, research stated, "As wildland fires in Alaska and its boreal forest become more extreme, preparing for the upcoming wildfire season has become increasingly challenging for fire managers. This study was developed in close collaboration with fire managers to address their need for advanced summer fire outlooks issued in March and May."


Financial supporters for this research include National Oceanic Atmospheric Admin (NOAA) - USA, National Science Foundation (NSF), State of Alaska, National Oceanic Atmospheric Admin (NOAA) - USA.
Our news journalists obtained a quote from the research from the University of Alaska Fairbanks, "Three seasonal forecast models are used to create summer fire outlooks: NOAA CFSv2, ECMWF SEAS5, and Me <acute accent >te <acute accent >oFrance System8. Variables from these forecasts are used to calculate Buildup Index (BUI), an operationally used fire weather index from the Canadian Forest Fire Danger Rating System. The BUI outlooks are evaluated based on Alaska wildfire subseason, BUI tercile, and predictive service area subregion with the area under the ROC curve (AUROC), Heidke, and mean squared error (MSE) skill scores. Skill is greatest for the wind (April 1-June 10) and drought (July 21-August 9) subseasons and in the Western Boreal subregion of Alaska. Combining the models into a multimodel ensemble increases forecast skill by an average of 11% (19%) for the March (May) forecast AUROC score and an average of 87% (92%) for the March (May) forecast Heidke skill score. May forecasts typically have equal or greater skill than March forecasts, with the greatest increases in skill seen during the wind subseason. However, instances of higher Heidke and MSE skill scores for March forecasts, especially in later subseasons and during large fires years, could be explained by the seasonally decreased predictability. Alaska's wildfire season has changed over the past 30 years. The season has lengthened by about a month, and extreme fire events have become more frequent. Fire managers begin preparing for the upcoming fire season in March, several weeks before the administrative start of the fire season (April 1) and about three months before the typical peak in late June to early July. With the increasing availability of dynamical seasonal forecasts, the Alaska fire management community has expressed growing interest in using these tools for operational planning. In this study, we used March-initialized seasonal forecasts to generate early-season outlooks of the Buildup Index (BUI), a key fire weather variable. These outlooks align with the timing of critical early-season decision-making by fire managers, including resource allocation and national coordination. After several years of providing these outlooks, fire managers requested additional outlooks initialized in May to support decisions after the season has begun but before its peak. Although May-initialized forecasts are typically more skillful, our early focus on the more challenging March forecasts reflects our commitment to meeting fire managers' needs. This long-term collaboration, including presentations at spring meetings and sustained engagement through biweekly calls, has helped refine our scientific focus-e.g., by emphasizing the duff-burning subseason and the timing of seasonending rains. Throughout this work, we have taken an operational perspective, aiming to keep methods computationally efficient to accommodate the large data volumes and time-sensitive decision-making. As such, the current study establishes a baseline of forecast skill using relatively streamlined methods. This foundation allows the fire management community to explore ways to tailor and enhance forecast products, such as applying more advanced bias correction techniques for high-latitude models or refining skill assessments by subregion or subseason. It also creates a platform for optimizing the multimodel ensemble approach, either by adjusting model weights or expanding the ensemble membership. This work represents one component of a broader effort to improve seasonal fire weather prediction in Alaska. As collaboration continues, these BUI outlooks can be integrated with emerging long-range forecasting products for fuels and lightning to build a more comprehensive picture of the upcoming fire season."
According to the news editors, the research concluded: "We remain actively engaged with fire managers, sharing updates during spring and fall operational meetings and incorporating their feedback in ongoing research and tool development."
For more information on this research see: On Using Dynamical Seasonal Forecasts To Develop Management-driven Wildland Fire Outlooks In Alaska. Climate Services, 2025;39. Climate Services can be contacted at: Elsevier, Radarweg 29, 1043 Nx Amsterdam, Netherlands.
The news correspondents report that additional information may be obtained from Cecilia Borries-Strigle, University of Alaska Fairbanks, Dept. of Atmospheric Sciences, Fairbanks, AK 99775, United States. Additional authors for this research include Uma S. Bhatt, Peter A. Bieniek, Mitchell Burgard, Richard L. Thoman, Alison York, Robert H. Ziel, Eric Stevens and Heidi Strader.
The direct object identifier (DOI) for that additional information is: https://doi.org/10.1016/j.cliser.2025.100592. This DOI is a link to an online electronic document that is either free or for purchase, and can be your direct source for a journal article and its citation.
Keywords for this news article include: Fairbanks, Alaska, United States, North and Central America, Climatology, Science, University of Alaska Fairbanks.

urn:contentItem:6GF4-Y533-RS54-B271-00000-00Rain gives firefighters big boost during recent rash of lightning storms2025-08-04T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:00:09ZLexisNexisSTATE AND REGIONAL NEWSRain gives firefighters big boost during recent rash of lightning stormsJayson JacoBaker City Herald, Ore.

The series of towering stormclouds that have swept across Baker County over the past week or so have brought copious amounts of what Al Crouch fears, but also of what he welcomes.

Lightning and rain.

“The recent storms are a double-edged sword,” Crouch, the fire mitigation specialist for the BLM’s Vale District, said on Monday morning, Aug. 4. “Lots of lightning has kept our fire crews pretty busy, but they also brought rain to moderate the fire danger.”

That moderating effect is reflected in the size of the lightning-sparked fires, a dramatic difference from 2024, the summer of “megafires” in Eastern Oregon — blazes that burn more than 100,000 acres.

Several fires surpassed that threshold last summer, including Oregon’s biggest blaze, the 294,000-acre Durkee Fire, sparked by lightning on July 17, 2024.

This summer, by contrast, the wildfire log is rife with so-called “spot fires” — those that cover less than one-tenth of an acre.

Rain is a key factor in keeping fires at such modest dimensions, Crouch said.

Although showers that accompany thunderstorms don’t always douse flames, the moisture, by slowing the fire’s spread, can give firefighters time to arrive while the blaze is benign.

The biggest recent fire, the 1,124-acre Long Tom Fire sparked on July 29 about 10 miles west of Huntington, was one of the few that wasn’t splattered with rain, Crouch said.

The fire started in an area surrounded by land scorched by the Durkee Fire a year ago.

“It got pushed around by the wind from thunderstorms, which is why it got as big as it did,” Crouch said.

The Juniper Fire, reported on the evening of July 31, burned about 57 acres a mile or so northwest of Durkee before crews controlled the blaze.

The Blue Mountain Interagency Dispatch Center in La Grande lists 43 fires in Northeastern Oregon from July 28 through Aug. 3, and only one burned more than an acre.

The Lake Creek Fire burned 500 acres about 9 miles southeast of Pilot Rock on July 31.

Crouch said the predominance of spot fires reflects not only widespread rainfall and relatively low fire danger, but also the rapid response by local, state and federal fire agencies.

“We’re having a very strong interagency response,” he said.

Crouch said last summer’s rash of megafires “put a lot of people on edge” and has spurred fire crews, including the many volunteer-run fire districts and rangeland fire protection associations, to respond as quickly as possible.

“We’ve had a lot of resources coming to the table,” he said.

Cody Kingsbury, wildland fire supervisor at the Oregon Department of Forestry’s Baker City office, agreed with Crouch that last summer, with multiple fires spreading across tens of thousands of acres in a single day, will remain memorable for firefighters.

“I think last year had people a little jaded — I know I was,” Kingsbury said.

Fire danger

This summer’s weather has been drastically different from 2024, a trend that also has contributed to the comparatively tranquil fire season thus far, Crouch and Kingsbury said.

July 2024, when most of the region’s megafires started, was the hottest month on record at the Baker City Airport, where the average daily high temperature was 94.9 degrees. Rainfall was about half of average at 0.27 of an inch.

This July, by contrast, was the wettest at the airport since 2015, with a total of 1.16 inches.

The average high this July was 85.9 degrees, the coolest since 2016 and only slightly above the long-term average of 85.6.

The combination of average temperatures and above average rainfall has kept fire danger indices below average for most of the fire season.

One index, the energy release component, which projects how fast a fire would spread, is below average in each of the eight zones in Northeastern Oregon as of Aug. 4. That’s been the case since about July 20.

The fire danger is significantly lower now than it was a year ago, Kingsbury said.

He said the spate of small fires has been a godsend for ODF firefighters, many of whom are newcomers.

They have had lots of fires to work on, but without the nearly constant crises that prevailed for much of last summer.

Looking ahead

Although Crouch and Kingsbury are pleased with how the fire season has progressed, both emphasized that early August historically is within the peak period for wildfire potential.

“We’ll see what the next six weeks looks like,” Crouch said. “But every day that passes is one less day of fire season.”

Crouch points out that in the grass and sagebrush country that makes up most of the BLM’s Vale District, the fuels dry rapidly even after a torrential downpour. Just a couple days of hot, dry and windy weather — typical for August — can erase the beneficial effects of rain.

At higher elevations, where forests dominate, the benefits persist longer, Crouch said.

Kingsbury said the frequent rain over the past month have kept wildfire fuel damper than usual, a major factor in fires that are more likely to smolder than to spread.

Although lightning has ignited most blazes over the past couple weeks, Crouch reminds residents that they can help mightily by complying with fire regulations — all burning is prohibited on the Vale District, and there are restrictions on some national forest land in the region.

“If we’re busy chasing lightning fires the last thing we need is a human-caused fire,” he said.

The Malheur National Forest, as of Wednesday, Aug. 6, will ease public use restrictions on the south side of the forest. Currently, campfires are allowed only in designated recreation sites in that part of the forest.

Fire restrictions are available at bmidc.org/restrictions.shtml

Fire dispatch logs are posted at:

• www.wildwebe.net/incidents?dc_Name=ORVAC

• www.wildwebe.net/incidents?dc_Name=ORBMC

urn:contentItem:6G65-R6T3-S8P8-P12K-00000-00Research from University of Electronic Science and Technology of China Reveals New Findings on Remote Sensing (CSNet: A Remote Sensing Image Semantic Segmentation Network Based on Coordinate Attention and Skip Connections)2025-07-04T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:00:08ZLexisNexisTECHNOLOGY - REMOTE SENSINGResearch from University of Electronic Science and Technology of China Reveals New Findings on Remote Sensing (CSNet: A Remote Sensing Image Semantic Segmentation Network Based on Coordinate Attention and Skip Connections)


2025 JUL 04 (NewsRx) -- By a News Reporter-Staff News Editor at Tech Daily News -- A new study on remote sensing is now available. According to news reporting from Chengdu, People's Republic of China, by NewsRx journalists, research stated, "In recent years, the continuous development of deep learning has significantly advanced its application in the field of remote sensing. However, the semantic segmentation of high-resolution remote sensing images remains challenging due to the presence of multi-scale objects and intricate spatial details, often leading to the loss of critical information during segmentation."


Financial supporters for this research include Sichuan Science And Technology Program “research on Precise Identification of Forest Fire Risks For Distribution Lines of 35 Kv And Below Crossing Forest Areas”.
Our news correspondents obtained a quote from the research from University of Electronic Science and Technology of China: "To address this issue and enable fast and accurate segmentation of remote sensing images, we made improvements based on SegNet and named the enhanced model CSNet. CSNet is built upon the SegNet architecture and incorporates a coordinate attention (CA) mechanism, which enables the network to focus on salient features and capture global spatial information, thereby improving segmentation accuracy and facilitating the recovery of spatial structures. Furthermore, skip connections are introduced between the encoder and decoder to directly transfer low-level features to the decoder. This promotes the fusion of semantic information at different levels, enhances the recovery of fine-grained details, and optimizes the gradient flow during training, effectively mitigating the vanishing gradient problem and improving training efficiency. Additionally, a hybrid loss function combining weighted cross-entropy and Dice loss is employed. To address the issue of class imbalance, several categories within the dataset are merged, and samples with an excessively high proportion of background pixels are removed."
According to the news reporters, the research concluded: "These strategies significantly enhance the segmentation performance, particularly for small-sample classes. Experimental results from the Five-Billion-Pixels dataset demonstrate that, while introducing only a modest increase in parameters compared to SegNet, CSNet achieves superior segmentation performance in terms of overall classification accuracy, boundary delineation, and detail preservation, outperforming established methods such as U-Net, FCN, DeepLabv3+, SegNet, ViT, HRNe and BiFormert."
For more information on this research see: CSNet: A Remote Sensing Image Semantic Segmentation Network Based on Coordinate Attention and Skip Connections. Remote Sensing, 2025,17(12):2048. (Remote Sensing - http://www.mdpi.com/journal/remotesensing/). The publisher for Remote Sensing is MDPI AG.
A free version of this journal article is available at https://doi.org/10.3390/rs17122048.
Our news editors report that more information may be obtained by contacting Jiahao Li, School of Resources and Environment, University of Electronic Science and Technology of China, Chengdu 611731, People's Republic of China. Additional authors for this research include Hongguo Zhang, Liang Chen, Binbin He, Huaixin Chen.
Keywords for this news article include: University of Electronic Science and Technology of China, Chengdu, People's Republic of China, Asia, Remote Sensing, Technology.

urn:contentItem:6F2D-7CC3-RT5W-8335-00000-00Findings from Northeast Forestry University in Environment and Sustainability Research Reported (Novel Silica Hydrogel-based Forest Fire Extinguishing Agent: Construction, Fire Extinguishing Performance and Mechanism Study)2025-02-05T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:00:08ZLexisNexisENVIRONMENT - ENVIRONMENT AND SUSTAINABILITY RESEARCHFindings from Northeast Forestry University in Environment and Sustainability Research Reported (Novel Silica Hydrogel-based Forest Fire Extinguishing Agent: Construction, Fire Extinguishing Performance and Mechanism Study)


2025 FEB 05 (NewsRx) -- By a News Reporter-Staff News Editor at Ecology Daily News -- Current study results on Environment - Environment and Sustainability Research have been published. According to news reporting from Harbin, People's Republic of China, by NewsRx journalists, research stated, "The frequent occurrence of forest fires has caused a great threat to the ecological environment and the safety of human life and property. How to effectively prevent and control forest fires has become a top priority."


Financial supporters for this research include National Key R & D Program of China, National Natural Science Foundation of China (NSFC), Fundamental Research Funds for the Central Universities, Young Elite Scientist Sponsorship Program by Heilongjiang Province, Key Research and Development Projects in Heilongjiang Province, Heilongjiang Postdoctoral Foundation, Undergraduate Innovation Project for Northeast Forestry University.
The news correspondents obtained a quote from the research from Northeast Forestry University, "However, water-based fire extinguishing agents commonly used in forest fires possessed the problems of poor spraying effectiveness, adhesion and spreading, and fire extinguishing efficiency. Inspired by the porous thermal insulation materials, a novel silica hydrogel-based fire extinguishing agent (SiKP) was successfully prepared by micro-crosslinking silica aerogel and introducing phosphorus and potassium fire extinguishing elements. SiKP showed excellent high-temperature adhesion properties on wood surfaces and their pH meets the requirements of its application. After spraying SiKP, the open flame of the wood stacks was extinguished quickly within 2 s and the smoldering time of wood stacks was 29.71% less than that of pure water. The phosphorus- and potassiumcontaining free radicals and inert gases from the decomposition of SiKP effectively interrupted the free radical chain reaction and diluted the combustible gas concentration in gas phase. Besides, SiKP promoted the dehydration and charring of forest vegetation and the formation of a compact barrier char layer effectively prevents the transfer of heat and flammable volatiles in condensed phase. Consequently, the total heat and total smoke release of NW/Si3K3P6 were decreased by 51.05% and 72.86% compared with pure pine."
According to the news reporters, the research concluded: "This novel forest fire extinguishing agent with excellent adhesion, fire extinguishing, and sustained fire resistance properties shows great value for the prevention and control of forest fires."
This research has been peer-reviewed.
For more information on this research see: Novel Silica Hydrogel-based Forest Fire Extinguishing Agent: Construction, Fire Extinguishing Performance and Mechanism Study. Journal of Cleaner Production, 2025;486. Journal of Cleaner Production can be contacted at: Elsevier Sci Ltd, 125 London Wall, London, England. (Elsevier - www.elsevier.com; Journal of Cleaner Production - www.journals.elsevier.com/journal-of-cleaner-production/)
Our news journalists report that additional information may be obtained by contacting Bin Li, Northeast Forestry University, Coll Chem Chem Engn & Resource Utilizat, Heilongjiang Key Lab Mol Design & Preparat Flame R, Harbin 150040, People's Republic of China. Additional authors for this research include Minmin Xu, Yuxin Wei, Ao Qin, Yue Xu, Miaojun Xu and Lubin Liu.
The direct object identifier (DOI) for that additional information is: https://doi.org/10.1016/j.jclepro.2024.144490. This DOI is a link to an online electronic document that is either free or for purchase, and can be your direct source for a journal article and its citation.
Keywords for this news article include: Harbin, People's Republic of China, Asia, Environment and Sustainability Research, Environment, Alcohols, Hydrogel, Organic Chemicals, Polyethylene Glycols, Northeast Forestry University.

urn:contentItem:6GMG-RFH3-S6GH-N2DY-00000-00The war to make up the data after extinguishing the fires: How many hectares have burned in each community?2025-08-30T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:00:08ZLexisNexisThe war to make up the data after extinguishing the fires: How many hectares have burned in each community?


Forest fires have devastated 362,473 hectares throughout the country during these weeks of August, according to data from the European Commission's European Forest Fire Information System (EFFIS) of Copernicus, as of the 30th of this month. 138,689 hectares have burned in Galicia. The Government of Alfonso Rueda, however, speaks of 95,000, that is, about 45,000 hectares less than those counted by European satellites. "It is not a debatable difference. The gap is huge, we are talking about hiding almost a third of the Copernicus estimate. The Xunta has the real data, but prefers to make up the reality to make it seem that the environmental and property damage is less," says Francisco Lueiro, spokesman for the environmental group Arco Iris.


It is true that the statistics published by the European satellite, practically in real time, are provisional and take into account all the burnt surface that the cameras capture from tens of kilometers away. What the communities usually do afterwards is to discount all those areas that have survived the flames, known as islands, as well as roads, pastures and agricultural or urban land. "The Xunta, at the same time, usually increases its own figure until the two are close. We are not so much talking about a technical issue, as a communication strategy," say various brigadistas consulted by Público, who prefer not to make their identities public. The Consellería de Medio Rural confirms to this media that the data they have revealed this week may undergo variations because, "while the outbreaks are not controlled or extinguished", "the exact areas" that the fire has devastated "cannot be known".
The regional administration also recalls that in its calculations "the hectares of agricultural nature are not counted" and tries to minimize the controversy generated by the obvious gap that exists for now between the two data. "Within the perimeter of the fires there are still unburned areas. The difference with Copernicus may respond to this issue (...) The satellite does not distinguish well and we prefer to play it safe," the ministry responds. The Xunta not only rejects the accusations of lack of transparency, but also emphasizes: "Every year, with the update of the Pladiga [plan for prevention and defense against forest fires], the technical information (...) of all forest fires of the previous year is recorded with total clarity". The problem is that the aforementioned plan is usually presented in the spring of the following year, that is, almost ten months after the high-risk period, when practically no one comes anymore to collate information on the number of hectares razed by the fires of the previous season.
Related to this topic
Opinion
The Spanish government's new policy to reduce the number of fires in Spain
Ana Pardo de Vera
Copernicus has also published its estimates for the rest of the communities affected by the fires of the last four weeks. The European satellite puts the number of hectares burned this August in Castilla y León at 150,000. Extremadura, for its part, would have been damaged an area of 45,000 hectares. Público has contacted both administrations. The first has not responded to the questions of this medium, but even two members of different regional brigades have been able to confirm that no daily data of burned hectares are given and that, once the fire season is over, "make the measurement and usually lower what comes from the satellite", again excluding non-forest land and "areas that have not burned completely, in which there has been a little green, however little. The objective, according to these professionals, would be "to make believe that less forests and areas have burned than have actually burned, to appear less serious".
The Government of Maria Guardiola does offer quantitative results as it progresses in extinguishing the outbreaks, both in the INFOEX portal and in the channels of 112 Extremadura. The General Directorate of Fires explains to Público how its operation works: "We have a coordination helicopter that performs orthophotographs and allows us to know the area affected by each fire almost in real time". The popular, here yes, put in value both their own system and the work of the EFFIS satellites. "We usually compare it and the two measurements are similar, very reliable and very even", insist from the department.
Asturias, where 2,405 hectares have burned according to Copernicus, made a first estimate from EFFIS calculations, "based on satellite images and spectral analysis, which guarantees the reliability of the data", as sources from the Department of Mobility, Environment and Forest Management confirm to this newspaper. The Principality's environmental agents will now review the satellite's provisional reports to make the appropriate adjustments before transferring the final sum to the Ministry for Ecological Transition and the Demographic Challenge. This portfolio has not been able to explain to Público before the publication of this article how it makes the total computation of the statistics of all the communities and if it plans to establish from now on a unified criterion to measure the burned areas in the whole of the State.
The use of last century's means to quantify ashes
This is, in fact, another of the great dilemmas for political representatives and professionals in the sector. Galicia, for example, uses aerial photographs and manual tools to measure the extent of what has been devastated by the flames. This is how the Consellería de Medio Rural itself explains it to Público: "The measurement systems, while the outbreaks have not been extinguished, take as a basis the information offered by aerial means [photographs from helicopters or airplanes that are then digitized] and also the personnel operating from the ground (...) Once the fires are under control, GPS is used to determine the affected areas". The Xunta, in fact, insists: "These systems have a wide international accreditation in the sector". Forestry experts, however, consider that satellite measurement is much faster, more accurate and effective, especially in the face of fires as large and virulent as those of this summer.
Related to this topicThe wave of fires fuels in the fachosphere the hoaxes that feed the climate emergency denialist narrative
Juan Oliver

"The manual perimetry can help you to classify a small fire, but not one of 15,000 or 20,000 hectares. In these cases, satellites are the finest tool. GPS or aerial photos can lead to errors, mainly human. Satellite is pure mathematics: you have five hectares, subtract two [not burned] and you have three left. It's like a chessboard, there's no trick to it," compares Carlos Madrigal, territorial dean of the Madrid Community of the Official Association of Forestry Technical Engineers. Galicia also has "180 fixed surveillance cameras" deployed in its forests. It is not, however, the only community that uses "conventional" formulas despite the technological advances made in the last ten years. Castilla-La Mancha and Asturias, in fact, are two of the few that use satellites to carry out these tasks. "The difference is evident," says the engineer.
What all the autonomous regions do do is to cover before the end of the year a standardized fire report through the Ministry for Ecological Transition and Demographic Challenge. This also has its nuances. The environmental agents of each community collect in this form the definitive data of burned areas and incorporate other technical aspects such as the type of vegetation or the volume of wood burned. The report is the same for all the territories, but each one, however, measures the number of hectares affected in its own way. "The calculation would have to be done in the same way in all the communities, especially with regard to large forest fires. It is true that the competences are autonomous, but many things should be unified at a national level and one of them is, without a doubt, the measurement of surfaces", Madrigal continues.
Related to this issueGalicia, the community that burns the most while the Xunta renounces to protect 88% of the territory with Red Natura
Juan Oliver
Image of the burned area in Larouco (Ourense) by the worst fire in the history of Galicia.Brais Lorenzo / EFEGalicia only informs of burns of more than 20 hectares
The way in which each community reports fires is also the subject of a separate chapter. Galicia is here again one of the most controversial, given, however, that it is the only one that has an official and specific account to make communications that have to do with forest emergencies: @incendios085. Castilla y León, for its part, has the INFORCYL platform, which reports the progress of the fires "in real time", without including, as had been warned, the number of hectares burned. The Government of Mañueco also sends during the high-risk period two daily press reports, one at 10.00 and another at 19.00. "And all the fires that are known, as long as they are over one hectare, are entered in the database we work with, from where the press report comes out," explains Agustín Argulo, fire technician in the regional operation and national environmental delegate of CSIF. Extremadura uses INFOEX accounts. And Barbón uses the networks of 112 Asturias and issues daily press releases "depending on the evolution of the fires", but reporting on all of them, "from a small one to one of hundreds of hectares".
Related to this issueThe workers of the Galician public television ask for the dismissal of those in charge of news for the coverage of the fires
What is then the controversy with Galicia? The PP came to the Government of the Xunta in 2009. Feijóo ousted the bipartite and took control of the Galician Parliament. The PP launched that same year an "internal instruction" to notify only through public channels the fires of more than 20 hectares, as warned by legal and sectoral sources consulted by Público and confirmed by the Department of Rural Environment. The administration also warns of those outbreaks that affect natural parks and those that are in operational situation 2. "The criterion of proactively reporting fires of more than 20 hectares was established in 2009, based on technical criteria and responsibility," they argue from Medio Rural. The reason would be, they say, to avoid a possible call effect. "Reporting each and every one of the records that occur could generate social alarm and have an undesirable effect of encouraging incendiary action," they specify from the Consellería.
The Xunta maintains, however, that it offers "detailed and timely information on any outbreak for which media professionals are consulted, regardless of its surface area". The measure was taken three years after another of the great waves of fires that threatened Galicia, the emergency of 2006. The community was then governed by PSdG and BNG. "It is not normal to bet from a public body to hide all fires of less than 20 hectares, because we have many and equally affect our heritage," criticize from the collective Arco Iris. The brigadistas consulted by Público emphasize, however, that this is a "purely informative question", because both they and the Xunta "really know what is burning", and ask to abandon "for once" the electoral battle: "It is useless to make up the results. To do so is a political decision and fire does not understand political colors".

SECTION 2 CORPORATE PROFILE AND INDEPENDENT RATINGS

2.1 Activities

Weyerhaeuser Company, headquartered in Seattle, Washington, is one of the largest private owners of timberlands in the world, with a history dating back to 1900. Its core business activities center on sustainable forest management, timber harvesting, and the production of wood products. The company''s largest sources of revenue come from its Timberlands segment, which includes the sale of logs and timber, and its Wood Products segment, which manufactures and distributes lumber, engineered wood, and other building materials primarily for residential and commercial construction. Additionally, Weyerhaeuser operates a Real Estate, Energy, and Natural Resources segment, focusing on land sales and renewable energy opportunities. Among its business lines, the Wood Products segment has shown notable growth, driven by strong demand in the housing and construction markets. With a commitment to environmental stewardship, Weyerhaeuser continues to balance profitability with sustainable practices across its extensive land holdings. It is the NYSE's 5th largest Building materials & fixtures company by market capitalisation.

In FY 2024, the top earner of Revenue was WOOD PRODUCTS [68%] followed by TIMBERLANDS [26.9%] at Rank 2 and REAL ESTATE & ENR [5.1%] at Rank 3. In FY 2024, revenue growth was highest in REAL ESTATE & ENR [7.7%] .

4.1 Press Releases and Corporate Wire

Press Release article 1 of 12, 263 words

September 04: Weyerhaeuser Outlines Strategic Goals for Sustainable Growth

Weyerhaeuser Company has outlined its strategic goals aimed at enhancing shareholder value and operational efficiency. On the 4th of September 2025, Weyerhaeuser released presentation materials for investors, emphasizing its commitment to disciplined capital allocation and sustainable practices.

The company set forth several key targets, including a significant $1 billion investment in timberlands by 2025. Additionally, Weyerhaeuser aims to grow its annual EBITDA from natural climate solutions to $100 million and increase lumber production by 5% each year. These targets reflect Weyerhaeuser 's focus on fostering growth while prioritizing environmental sustainability.

Weyerhaeuser also reiterated its leadership in Environmental, Social, and Governance (ESG) performance, with a goal of achieving net-zero emissions by 2040. Furthermore, the company is committed to maintaining robust shareholder returns through a sustainable dividend policy. The recent analyst rating on Weyerhaeuser stock (WY) is a Hold, with a price target set at $28.00.

According to Spark, TipRanks' AI Analyst, Weyerhaeuser's overall stock score indicates a stable financial position, backed by strong cash conversion capabilities. However, the company faces challenges in revenue and profit growth, and technical analysis suggests a lack of momentum in the stock. Despite these hurdles, Weyerhaeuser's strategic initiatives and commitment to shareholder returns remain positive indicators for investors.

As the largest private owner of timberlands in North America, Weyerhaeuser operates across various sectors, including timberlands, real estate, energy, and natural resources. The company manages 10.4 million acres in the U.S. and licenses an additional 14 million acres in Canada, emphasizing sustainable forestry practices and carbon solutions.

Press Release article 2 of 12, 288 words

September 02: Weyerhaeuser Concludes Sale of Princeton Lumber Mill to Gorman Group

Weyerhaeuser Company has completed the sale of its lumber mill in Princeton, British Columbia, to the Gorman Group. This transaction, initially announced in May, includes the transfer of Weyerhaeuser's associated timber licenses in British Columbia, which are expected to be finalized in the coming months, subject to regulatory review and customary closing conditions.

As part of the sale, Weyerhaeuser received approximately $60 million USD upfront, with additional proceeds tied to the transfer of the timber licenses. The company has recognized a gain from the sale but anticipates a tax liability of about $11 million USD as a result of the transaction. This sale reflects Weyerhaeuser's ongoing strategy to optimize its operations and focus on its core business areas.

Established in 1900, Weyerhaeuser is among the largest private owners of timberlands worldwide, managing approximately 10.4 million acres in the U.S. and additional public timberlands in Canada. The company is recognized for its commitment to sustainability, operating all its timberlands in compliance with internationally recognized forestry standards. In 2024, Weyerhaeuser reported net sales of $7.1 billion and employed around 9,400 people globally.

The Gorman Group, a family-owned business founded in 1951, operates multiple divisions in Southern British Columbia and northern Washington state, employing about 900 individuals. The company is well-regarded for its high-value lumber products, particularly in the home finishing and renovation markets. The acquisition of Weyerhaeuser's mill aligns with Gorman Group's long-term strategy of enhancing its operational capabilities and market presence.

Weyerhaeuser's decision to divest its Princeton mill is part of a broader trend in the timber industry, where companies are reassessing their portfolios to focus on areas with higher growth potential.

Press Release article 3 of 12, Source: WEC, 75 words

August 12: Weyerhaeuser quarterly dividends steady

Weyerhaeuser today announced a quarterly dividend of 21.0c per share for Q2/2025; unchanged from the previous quarter (Q1/2025) dividend of 21.0c. The ex-dividend date is Friday, August 29, 2025 and the record date is Friday, August 29, 2025 and it is payable on Friday, September 12. Total dividends per share paid in the 12 months ended August 12 were 82.0c.

May 28: Weyerhaeuser, Firefighter Behavioral Health Alliance Partner for Fourth Year to Provide Mental Health Resources for Wildland Firefighters

Fighting Fires Together campaign raises awareness and helps address mental health challenges of wildland firefighting

SEATTLE, May 28, 2025- Weyerhaeuser Company (NYSE: WY) and Firefighter Behavioral Health Alliance (FBHA) today announced an extension of their Fighting Fires Together campaign, a partnership that provides specialized mental health support for wildland firefighters and their families across the Pacific Northwest.

Fighting Fires Together, now in its fourth year, addresses the often-overlooked mental health impacts of wildland firefighting in isolated, hazardous and highly stressful conditions. Through a free online resource hub, first responders can find specially designed content, including videos about Post Traumatic Stress Disorder (PTSD), depression, anxiety and suicide prevention, along with mental health tips, educational articles and contacts for occupationally aware support groups and counselors in Oregon, Washington and British Columbia.

Weyerhaeuser's support for wildland firefighting efforts in the Pacific Northwest began in the aftermath of the Yacolt Burn in 1902, when the company began advocating for Washington's first forest fire legislation and the funding of community fire prevention education and patrols. Today, as Weyerhaeuser celebrates its 125th anniversary, the company continues to play an active role in fire prevention and response through its forest management operations. Weyerhaeuser employees and contractors receive annual fire readiness training, build fire breaks and containment lines, conduct aerial surveys and deploy tanker trucks, helicopters and quick-response crews to wildland fires.

"After launching the Fighting Fires Together campaign with FBHA four years ago, we're proud to continue this effort to support wildland firefighters and their mental health as they work in challenging conditions to protect our communities," says Bill Frings, vice president of Western Timberlands for Weyerhaeuser.

May 22: Weyerhaeuser Acquiring High-Quality Timberlands in North Carolina and Virginia

Capitalizing on unique off-market opportunity to further enhance Southern Timberlands portfolio with highly productive and strategically located acreage

SEATTLE, May 22, 2025 - Weyerhaeuser Company (NYSE: WY) today announced an agreement to acquire approximately 117,000 acres of high-quality timberlands in North Carolina and Virginia from Roanoke Timberlands LLC, a subsidiary of Roseburg Forest Products, for $375 million. Comprised of mature, highly productive timberlands, the acreage will be well-integrated with existing Weyerhaeuser timberland and mill operations in North Carolina, will expand the company's footprint into attractive markets in southeastern Virginia and will offer substantial alternative value opportunities. The acquisition is expected to deliver immediate and sustained portfolio-leading cash flows within the company's Southern Timberlands business.

Key attributes of the acquisition:

Located in strong and growing sawlog and fiber markets in the U.S. South Primarily fee ownership with 81 percent planted pine acreage, strong site productivity and favorable all-weather logging operability Mature planted pine age class expected to produce an average annual harvest of 7.4 tons per acre (or 860,000 tons) over the first five years Expected to deliver an average annual timber free cash flow yield of 5.1 percent over the first five years Significant optionality to capture additional upside from real estate, natural climate solutions and natural resource opportunities "These are exceptional timberlands, and we're excited and well-positioned to capitalize on this unique off-market opportunity," said Devin W. Stockfish, president and chief executive officer. "As we've demonstrated over the last several years, we are committed to active portfolio management across our unmatched timber holdings and have remained disciplined in our approach to growing the value of our timberlands - including through strategically targeted private transactions like the one we're announcing today.

May 21: Weyerhaeuser to Sell Princeton, B.C., Lumber Mill to Gorman Group

Agreement with local buyer includes manufacturing facility and associated timber licenses in British Columbia

SEATTLE, May 21, 2025 - Weyerhaeuser Company (NYSE: WY) today announced it has reached an agreement to sell its lumber mill in Princeton, British Columbia, to the Gorman Group, owners of Gorman Bros. Lumber Ltd., a family-owned wood products manufacturer headquartered in West Kelowna, B.C. The purchase price is approximately $120 million CAD in cash, which includes Weyerhaeuser's manufacturing facility, all associated timber license assets in British Columbia and the value of working capital, which will be subject to customary purchase price adjustments at closing.

Weyerhaeuser and Gorman Group have a long-standing relationship in Canada. Gorman Bros. Lumber is currently the Princeton mill's largest customer, and Gorman Group has operated in Canada for more than 75 years, with offices and facilities in B.C. and Washington state.

"We are grateful to all the dedicated employees who contributed to the success of our Princeton operations over the years," says Devin W. Stockfish, president and chief executive officer for Weyerhaeuser. "The community has always been incredibly welcoming and supportive of our mill and people, and it was important for us to sell to a local buyer with deep roots in the region. Gorman has been a great customer and strategic partner, and we believe this will be a seamless transition that will position the mill for future success in a challenging operating environment - providing long-term certainty for the mill and the broader community."

"Weyerhaeuser's Princeton operation will be a natural fit with the Gorman Group," says Nick Arkle, chief executive officer of the Gorman Group. "We've had a strong connection to the Princeton operation for many years, and we know firsthand the skill, commitment and quality that define its team.

MANAGEMENT'S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS (MD&A)

WHAT YOU WILL FIND IN THIS MD&A

For Management's Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of Operations (MD&A) related to the year ended December 31, 2022, refer to this same section in our 2023 annual report on Form 10-K as filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission on February 16, 2024.

ECONOMIC AND MARKET CONDITIONS AFFECTING OUR OPERATIONS

Our market conditions and the strength of the broader U.S. economy are, and will continue to be, influenced by the trajectory of activity in the U.S. housing and repair and remodel segments, inflation trends and interest rates. The demand for sawlogs within our Timberlands segment is directly affected by domestic production of wood-based building products. The strength of the U.S. housing market, particularly new residential construction, strongly affects demand in our Wood Products segment, as does repair and remodeling activity. Seasonal weather patterns impact the level of construction activity in the U.S., which in turn affects demand for our logs and wood products. Our Timberlands segment, specifically the Western region, is also affected by export demand and trade policy. Japanese housing starts are a key driver of export log demand in Japan. The demand for pulpwood from our Timberlands segment is directly affected by the production of pulp, paper and oriented strand board (OSB), as well as the demand for biofuels, such as wood-burning pellets made from pulpwood. Our Timberlands segment is also influenced by the availability of harvestable timber. In general, Western log markets are highly tensioned by available supply, while Southern log markets have more available supply. However, additional mill capacity being added in the U.S.

SECTION 5 WEYERHAEUSER 10-Q: 12 CONSEQUENTIAL MANAGEMENT DECISIONS

Strategic Expansion of Engineered Wood Products Capacity

Management has committed $500 million to constructing a new TimberStrand facility in Monticello, Arkansas, beginning in 2025, with operations expected by 2027. This investment is projected to expand engineered wood products capacity by 10 million cubic feet, positioning Weyerhaeuser to seize greater market share in the growing housing sector. While the long-term growth and revenue potential align with favorable housing trends, the funding approach-whether via existing cash or external financing-could pressure short-term liquidity or increase debt levels.

Shareholder Value Enhancement Through New $1 Billion Buyback Program

Following completion of a prior program, management authorized a new $1 billion share repurchase initiative in May 2025. This move underscores confidence in company valuation and enhances earnings per share by reducing outstanding shares. While the initiative aligns with the shareholder return framework targeting 75-80% of Adjusted FAD, it reflects a strategic trade-off by potentially limiting capital allocation flexibility during potential market volatility.

Maintaining Dividend Stability Amid Economic Challenges

Weyerhaeuser continues its cash dividend framework, targeting a 75-80% payout of Adjusted FAD, and has paid $304 million in 2025 dividends thus far. The year-to-date payout decline-due primarily to an absence of supplemental dividends in Q1-highlights the company's adaptability to fluctuating cash flows. For income-focused investors, this consistent dividend policy provides predictability, though variability in Adjusted FAD may influence future distributions.

Strengthened Liquidity with an Updated Credit Facility

The company amended and restated its revolving credit facility in June 2025, increasing capacity to $1.75 billion and extending maturity to 2030. This ensures access to substantial liquidity without current borrowings, providing operational flexibility while reducing refinancing risks during economic uncertainty. The alignment of covenant compliance further supports Weyerhaeuser's credit profile.

Capital Optimization through Debt Repayment and Refinancing

Management refinanced maturing debt by repaying $210 million in debentures while issuing a $300 million senior unsecured term loan maturing in 2030. This strategic action reduced the weighted average interest rate, trimming interest expense by $2 million year-to-date, while preserving $592 million in cash and full credit availability. For investors, this showcases disciplined capital allocation, though possible fluctuations in interest rates remain a key consideration.

Focused Capital Investments to Drive Operational Efficiency

Excluding the Monticello project, management outlined $400 million in planned 2025 capital expenditures, with $200 million deployed so far. This includes both Timberland and Wood Products maintenance expansions designed to sustain production efficiency. Despite a year-over-year increase, such investments affirm a long-term strategy to sharpen competitiveness-though revenue pressure could strain cash flow in adverse market conditions.

Expansion into Carbon Markets to Capture Sustainability Growth

Weyerhaeuser progresses in leveraging its natural climate solutions, capitalizing on the growing demand for carbon credits and renewable energy. By positioning itself within key sustainability sectors, management aims to unlock new revenue streams while aligning with global decarbonization goals. Though regulatory adjustments and market development require monitoring, this initiative offers potential upside for forward-looking investors.

Unlocking Value Through Strategic Divestitures

The announced sale of a wood products manufacturing facility (pending regulatory approvals) reflects Weyerhaeuser's strategy to streamline operations and optimize its asset base. If successful, this move could free up cash for reinvestment in higher-margin opportunities and improve overall profitability. However, pending closures introduce timing uncertainties for short-term financial performance.

Timberland Acquisition to Strengthen Strategic Resource Base

Management advanced a timberland acquisition that remains subject to regulatory approval. This investment supports long-term timber supply needs for the Timberlands segment while positioning the company in tightening log markets. The targeted synergies enhance revenue potential, though integration risks and upfront costs require careful oversight.

Operational Efficiency Improvements Amid Inflationary Pressures

Initiatives to restructure manufacturing processes and reduce costs address inflation-driven challenges related to raw materials, energy, and labor. By improving cost structures, Weyerhaeuser aims to mitigate margin compression and enhance profitability. Successful implementation will be key, especially given labor market constraints influencing production continuity.

Proactive Risk Management for Contingent Liabilities

Reserves for litigation and environmental responsibilities demonstrate management's financial diligence in safeguarding against operational uncertainties. By maintaining adequate coverage for contingent liabilities, Weyerhaeuser bolsters its balance sheet resilience. However, potential over-reserving may tie up capital unnecessarily and requires vigilant management assessment.

Prioritizing Workforce Stability Amid Labor Market Tightness

Recognizing a 4.1% unemployment rate as a constraint, Weyerhaeuser focused on hiring and talent retention across its segments. Stability in workforce availability ensures operational continuity and supports management's strategic initiatives. However, rising labor costs remain a potential margin-pressure risk-a critical area to monitor for sustained profitability.

urn:contentItem:6GS3-RCC3-RS40-Y3V5-00000-00The Ecofire case: what is happening with the viral Spanish invention against fires?2025-09-16T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:00:08ZLexisNexisThe Ecofire case: what is happening with the viral Spanish invention against fires?


In the middle of prime time television, César Sallent shows his invention and puts it to the test. He opens a jar filled with a dark brown liquid and dips a piece of polystyrene in it. Then, with a blowtorch, he starts to set it on fire. The liquid repels the fire and creates a crust that protects the plastic, preventing its destruction. People applaud. He doesn't stop there and does the same with a sheet of kitchen paper, and even risks his own hand, knowing that nothing will happen. For the final flourish, he drinks a shot of the product and simulates a live brush fire. Again, the wet vegetable holds up while the rest burns. With everyone impressed by the ingenuity, he closes the performance with a devastating message: the administrations know about his creation, but almost no one has bought it in the worst year of fires in the history of Spain.


Sallent is the inventor of Ecofire, a product of Aragonese origin that has been resonating for two years in the media and social networks. Every time there is a wave of fires, this liquid appears. A secret formula with a national signature that, according to its creators, overnight would make it possible to extinguish fires better and faster, in addition to protecting firefighters and the population. However, the final message remains the same: very few are buying it. What is really happening with this invention? The creators blame the situation on the lack of interest in the protection of the Administration, but El Confidencial has consulted several experts in the sector who give other answers.
"The first thing that strikes anyone who knows a little about this is to see such a product advertised on television. We are talking about flame retardants, technical developments that, as such, reach the market in a different way. You don't need to convince the general public to buy it, but technicians, experts, administrations and laboratories," explains Guillermo Rein, professor of fire science in the Department of Mechanical Engineering at Imperial College London, who specializes in heat transfer, combustion and fire, using a combination of laboratory experiments and computer modeling. "Past that point, we can go into making a more technical analysis, which is what remains when the cameras are turned off and in this case leaves some doubts," adds the expert.
Since its launch, in 2022, Sallent has made demonstrations for all kinds of audiences, has recorded spectacular tests with the UME or companies such as the Madrid EMT or Iberdrola. He has shown it in the media as a revolutionary product and as a unique liquid, 100% biodegradable, ecological and organic. But when it comes down to it, among the large public entities that have acquired it, only the Provincial Council of Huesca appears, with equipment that has been delivered to isolated areas far from fire stations. Distributed globally under the umbrella of SimonRack, a company from Zaragoza dedicated to the manufacture of metal shelving, it can also be purchased in large supermarkets or hardware stores and they have a collaboration for a fire protection system for parking lots.
Its position in the generalist market has been gaining ground, but its creator does not get off his main objective: forest fires. He continues to insist, also in conversation with this newspaper, that the general problem lies with the administrations, which, for some unknown reason, have not wanted to negotiate with him and acquire an invention that could be key. But the experts' answers differ from this version. The technical characteristics of Ecofire and the lack of testing in real cases hinder this development.
The invention
To analyze Sallent's ingenuity, one could start with the formula, but its inventor refuses to give the ingredients, because he assures that it is like"Coca-Cola". As for the safety data sheets that, according to the law, all chemicals on the market must have, he assures that he doesn't even need them because "neither water, sugar nor orange juice have to have them". Therefore, in order to be able to compare his solution with others on the market, it is necessary to go further.
Ecofire is sold as a fire "blocker," but that term does not exist at the technical level, nor is its inclusion under discussion. As indicated in its efficacy report, issued by INIA-CIFOR (a CSIC institute), it is a long-term retardant. This is the name given to a type of chemical that serves, in the case of forest fires, as an extra tool to help extinguish the fire, slowing the spread of the fire and better controlling its progress. INIA results show that Sallent's solution is effective in this task, scoring top marks, and other certificates also show that it is non-toxic and non-hazardous to people and plants. But its problems are different.
"We are talking about a market in which it competes with products that have similar efficiency in the laboratory, but which, above all, and this is key, can be diluted in water. You have to provide this material to firefighting systems that have aircraft that need thousands and thousands of liters of liquid in each action," say industry sources who prefer to remain anonymous. "To use Ecofireit is recommended not to mix it, which makes it impossible to take it into account for these cases".
According to these experts, dilution makes it possible to size and be operational. "It is usually requested that these products can be diluted at the rate of 1/4 or 1/6 in water and Ecofire does not allow any dilution," they say. "For example, in each summer you can easily distribute about 1,000 tons of regular retardant, multiply that by six and you get the total amount of solution you would need to store if we were to use that product. There are no warehouses with such a capacity, and no way to transport the solution to the operation."
"According to the experiences that have come to me, technically it works, it prevents combustion. The problem is at what price. Not only monetary, which is very expensive compared to other retardants, but cleaning the equipment used with this product is quite cumbersome. This is a serious problem in forest fires," says Ignacio Villaverde, a forest firefighter and publicist. "A water pump is a very complex system and to avoid failures and breakdowns, which are very expensive, the system must be perfectly clean. And it takes half an hour or more to clean a pump properly, and be prepared to throw away 4,000L of water in the process," he adds.
Vicente Mans, an engineer who was part of the first Spanish team to study the use of retardants in forest fires, more than three decades ago, and who has been working in this sector ever since, confirms these needs. He does not directly mention the case of Ecofire, but clarifies the situation. "Today there are three types of retardants, those that change the pyrolysis of cellulose, those that work by evaporating water and cooling the environment and those that generate a film that protects materials from the impact of fire. The first are the most famous and in countries like France or the USA, which set the pace in this world, they don't even consider using others," he says.
"Here we are trying to develop standards that include them, because we must not stop innovation and we must provide regulations that allow everyone to compete and normalize their situation, but they do not yet exist," says Mans. "Dilution falls within the key points because you cannot transport thousands of liters in the middle of emergencies and in natural areas, it is not operational," he adds.
Ecofire would fall into the third group, those that create a film called intumescent that protects the material it coats from the action of fire for a certain time. It is something that has been seen for many years in paints and that in the case of the Aragonese invention goes one step further because it is a liquid. The lack of standardization of these inventions is already a handicap with which the solution is burdened and with which those who bet on acquiring it must deal, but it can be compared with the others if we talk in terms of effectiveness or toxicity.
Normally, those who change the pyrolysis of cellulose use chemicals that can be pollutants, the famous phosphates that mix with water, dye the discharges of airplanes so as not to confuse and leave a striking trace. That polluting part would give advantage to new proposals such as the one coming from Huesca, but in recent decades has already been generating an industry of ecological solutions to change this with the same type of solution. The CSIC itself, together with the company Primalchic and the Polytechnic University of Valencia, developed in 2020 an ecological product that contains "innocuous or very low toxicity compounds, which are also biodegradable and have a high extinguishing capacity", detailed its presentation.
Unlike Sallent's invention, the CSIC does provide a good part of its ingredients. In addition, it can be compared with Ecofire by the laboratory results and see that the INIA gives an almost identical result to both inventions. In some points it gives better results to the first one and in others to the other, but without great differences according to what can be consulted.
"Another problem with these intumescent products is that in order for them to be effective against all types of forest fires, the product must be spread perfectly on the vegetation so that it covers it completely. If you throw it on low grass, it may work. But if you throw it on an abandoned chestnut grove full of brambles, ferns, broom, heather, hawthorns, grasses and a thousand species that make up the undergrowth, it will be difficult to cover everything. You could try with aerial discharges, many of them. But we return to the fact that it would be very expensive that way," Villaverde points out. "That's why many of us don't consider it suitable for use in large-scale forest fire prevention or suppression."
The inventor
César Sallent, who comes from a family of inventors and who, before getting into this field, designed robots for the police and even solutions for the Melilla fence, defends his product. In conversation with this newspaper he assures that he has created a unique solution and that it should be bought as a key tool to protect citizens from forest fires. He denies conversations with other laboratories to approach the authorities, as well as assures that he has only received some comments from investment funds for the purchase of the formula. "It is not something to make money, but to sit down with the administration and create agreements that will save many people and put an end to the fires".
QUESTION: I have tried to look everywhere for the formula of your product, but I can't find it anywhere. However, I have seen that other retardant companies do detail part of the compound, why don't you do it?
ANSWER. You are not going to find the formula, it is not even in the patents I have published, which many people have already asked me about. I have it protected because it is not right that someone with my name can get on the Internet, see what it is made of and copy it. I can tell you that it has no polyphosphates and that it has a good percentage of water because otherwise it would be a paste, but nothing else. It's like Coca-Cola. It's organic stuff, edible stuff too.
Q. I have seen that INIA marks Ecofire as a long-term retardant, but you say it is a flame retardant. The term flame retardant does not exist in regulations.
A. Ecofire is not a retardant, it is a blocker, what happens is that INIA has done the most demanding tests it has, that is all. What we have done here is a very strong commitment to have a product that is organic, that is ecological, that all the components it contains are for human consumption. And what we have achieved is that where we apply it, it can withstand temperatures of 2,300 degrees, which are the maximum that I have managed to achieve with acetylene oxygen torches on a pine branch. The layer that expands when it comes into contact with fire is also refractory. That is very important. It has no thermal conductivity, sticks back to the materials and also avoids contact with oxygen. We have found that the solution can also work with class B fires and even with lithium batteries.
Q. They say it is 40 to 100 times more effective in firefighting than water, but I haven't found the certificate or study that proves that. Where do you get it from?
A. There is no certification, it comes from professional firefighters. That is what we have been told by firefighters who have used the product in real situations, in fires. They have called us and told us that they put out fires much faster and better. They tell me that while you need at least 50 liters of water for a firebreak, one liter of Ecofire is enough for them. It dissolves with water, and there have already been many smart people who have thrown that in my face, but it has to be that way to coexist with nature. In any case, 10 or 15 liters of water per square meter have to fall for it to disappear, which is an outrageous amount.
Q. Well, one of the weak points of the product, according to the experts, is that the water cannot be mixed, which complicates its use in large fires.
A. If you put 3000 liters of product in a truck and there are 100 liters of water, you are not going to notice the difference. Now, if you leave 1,000 liters, the effectiveness will drop quite a bit. But the important thing here is that we are talking about a product that can save the lives of lots of firefighters, lots of people, and this is something that I have already shown when I have appeared on television and in videos. And I have also shown it to Isaac Claver, president of the Provincial Council of Huesca, who has seen how it works and I have already given him several pieces of equipment so that he can deliver them to the towns of Huesca, so that they are protected. He has been concerned about the citizens, which is what politicians have to do, because it is shameful what is happening in this country.
Q. Why do you think that more administrations do not buy it?
A. It does not fit in my head. We have no competition, we have the firefighters of a lot of countries in love, big companies in Spain and other countries have already bought from us. I want people to have the product, which right now in Leroy Merlin a spray is worth about 16 euros, but if we sit down and negotiate millions of liters, it can be obtained in another way and at another price.
Q. Have you tried to present technical reports, go to tenders and so on to try to get them to buy it? Have you contacted laboratories to collaborate?
A. Everybody knows my product, I have appeared in the media, I was given more than 14 minutes on El Hormiguero.... I have made presentations everywhere, they know how to find me and that I can manufacture everything they need. They just have to be interested. As for the other laboratories, if my invention is already there, they don't have to spend their money on this, let them spend it on other things.
A new business niche
Sallent hopes that the authorities will start knocking on his door soon. However, other members of the industry, such as Justo Adámez, engineer and CEO of Ashes Fire, a consulting firm specializing in the sector, offer him another way out. According to Adámez, who has been working on firefighting systems for decades, Ecofire can be groundbreaking when it comes to battery fire protection. A new risk that is increasingly present due to the growth of devices such as electric cars.
"It has been shown that water is not the best to extinguish this type of fire and that new alternatives must be sought due to the characteristics of these fires. For this reason, retardants that create a film that covers batteries and insulates the fire are beginning to have a prominent position in the market," says the expert. "Right now I only know of two that are giving very interesting results, Ecofire and an American invention called Fike Blue. Both cases have demonstrated efficacy by flooding, i.e. you have to completely cover what is burning with this product to allow firefighters to act more safely and prevent the fire from spreading," he adds.
As Mans also points out, doubts in this regard are based on the fact that there is still no legislation on the matter and it is a niche to exploit. Hence, there is a lack of tests and certifications. "That is the big problem, that there is no standardization and it is still a world to be explored. For example, I have seen that Ecofire uses ceiling diffusers to spread its product, that cannot be so because the diffusers are only allowed with water, it is the only substance that can pass through them by regulation because they are complex systems that must be treated with great care, "he details.
To conclude, Guillermo Rein leaves a last message beyond the technique. "It is very dangerous to give the idea that something like forest fires, so complex and delicate, can be solved with a liquid. It leads people to trust and think that the necessary effort is not being made to fight them," he says. "From tests to actual operations is a big step, and in environments such as forest fires, even more so. That's why technicians have to be skeptical before buying any miracle product that appears on the TV."
In the middle of prime time television, César Sallent shows his invention and puts it to the test. He opens a jar filled with a dark brown liquid and dips a piece of polystyrene in it. Then, with a blowtorch, he starts to set it on fire. The liquid repels the fire and creates a crust that protects the plastic, preventing its destruction. People applaud. He doesn't stop there and does the same with a sheet of kitchen paper, and even risks his own hand, knowing that nothing will happen. For the final flourish, he drinks a shot of the product and simulates a live brush fire. Again, the wet vegetable holds up while the rest burns. With everyone impressed by theingenuity, closes the performance with a devastating message: the administrations are aware of its creation, but almost no one has acquired it in the worst fire year in the history of Spain.

urn:contentItem:6G71-48J3-SJ8D-K14J-00000-00Northland duo tackle world's longest paddling race2025-07-09T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:00:08ZLexisNexisREGIONALPg. A004Northland duo tackle world's longest paddling race

Two Northland men will spend a week kayaking 18 hours a day as part of the world's longest paddling race - The Yukon 1000.

Calvin Ball and Ryan Baxter will traverse 1609km across Canada and into Yukon territory in Alaska in a two-person kayak as part of the 30-team race.

The Northlanders have spent the last 10 months preparing for the once-in-a-lifetime adventure by kayaking 20km a day, hitting the gym and running.

The pair will encounter freezing waters, forest fire zones, bear territory and some of the most remote wilderness in the world.

In 2024, the race was won by Marlborough-Tasman residents Sophie Hart and Nathan Fa'avae in six days and 23 minutes - one of the fastest times recorded.

For Ball and Baxter, it isn't about winning, it's about the journey.

Having both biked the length of New Zealand, something like this was their perfect holiday.

"Instead of having a big overseas holiday, which most people would spend the same amount of money on, this is our holiday," Ball said.

"We have this mutual philosophy around you've got to do hard things to really grow," Baxter said.

"This just seemed like it ticked all the boxes in terms of outdoor, adventure, travel, dedication and friendship."

The pair are armed with about 130 items of gear, including dehydrated meals, satellite phones, spot trackers, a GPS, solar panels and a first aid kit.

They will start in Whitehorse, Canada, and finish at the Alaska Pipeline Bridge.

"There's going to be a lot of pain and a lot of suffering and a lot of fatigue, but for me, I'm looking forward to seeing what's on the other side of that," Ball said.

And the prize?

"It's quite a humble event in the sense that there's no finish line with a podium. It's just a bridge in the middle of nowhere," Ball said.

"You get a can of beer at the end and a handshake, and I guess for Ryan and I, that aligns quite nicely with how we go about life."

The race is considered only 40% kayaking - the rest was navigation and other survival skills.

They would have to map their way down 1600km of river, which freezes over each year, so when it melts again, the same paths may have moved.

There would be plenty of other hazards too.

Part of their compulsory gear list is masks and goggles due to the potential threat of forest fires.

Meanwhile, hypothermia was a real risk thanks to the glacier-fed waters they would be wading.

And then there's the wildlife.

"Bears are very active, so we have to take bear spray," Ball said.

While some might think them mad for taking on such a risky adventure, the pair said that's what they're all about.

Ball firmly believed there was an importance in "feeling small".

"In our urban, suburban lives, we forget how small we are. So when you're in a landscape like that it helps bring things into perspective."

They had a few goals in mind but the first was not to die, Baxter joked.

"Second is to finish the race - we've got 10 days to do it.

"Whatever our placing is, we'll be happy as long as we've done the best we can."

In true Kiwi form, their team name is "Get a Dog Up Ya", a homage to their Northland roots and can-do attitude.

Those who want to support the duo have been asked to donate to a Givealittle page they have launched.

The money will go towards sending a Northland teen who wouldn't otherwise have the means, to the outdoor adventure programme Outward Bound.

urn:contentItem:6G5Y-SGV3-RS26-W0BK-00000-00Research from Universidad Catolica de la Santisima Concepcion Provides New Study Findings on Physics (Improving Wildfire Resilience in the Mediterranean Central-South Regions of Chile)2025-07-03T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:00:08ZLexisNexisPHYSICSResearch from Universidad Catolica de la Santisima Concepcion Provides New Study Findings on Physics (Improving Wildfire Resilience in the Mediterranean Central-South Regions of Chile)


2025 JUL 03 (NewsRx) -- By a News Reporter-Staff News Editor at Physics Daily News -- Investigators publish new report on physics. According to news reporting from Concepcion, Chile, by NewsRx journalists, research stated, "Wildfires in central-south Chile, consistent with trends observed in other Mediterranean regions, are expected to become more frequent and severe, threatening ecosystems and impacting millions of people. This study aims to enhance wildfire resilience in the central-south regions of Chile through the provision of robust information on current wildfire management practices and comparison with successful alternatives implemented in other fire-prone Mediterranean regions."


Funders for this research include Anid.
The news correspondents obtained a quote from the research from Universidad Catolica de la Santisima Concepcion: "With this aim, we consulted 55 local stakeholders involved in wildfire management, and alongside a comparative analysis of wildfire statistics and resource allocation in selected Mediterranean regions, we critically assessed different strategies to improve wildfire prevention and management in central-south Chile. The comparative analysis indicated notable economic under-investment for wildfire prevention in Chile. Compared to other Mediterranean countries, Chile is clearly below in terms of investment in forest fire prevention, both in global (public investment) and specific terms ($ ha-1, GDP per capita). The experts consulted included fuel management, governance and community participation, territorial management, landscape planning, socioeconomic evaluation, and education and awareness as key aspects for wildfire prevention. The results of the questionnaire indicated that there was a broad consensus regarding the importance of managing biomass to reduce fuel loads and vegetation continuity, thereby enhancing landscape resilience. Landscape planning and territorial management were also emphasized as critical tools to balance ecological needs with those of local communities, mitigating wildfire risks. Fire-Smart management emerged as a nature-based solution and a promising integrated approach, combining fuel treatments with modeling, simulation, and scenario evaluation based on local and regional environmental data. Additionally, educational and social engagement tools were considered vital for addressing misconceptions and fostering community support."
According to the news reporters, the research concluded: "Besides a better integration of rural planning with social demands, this study underscores the urgent need to substantially increase the investment and significance of wildfire prevention measures in central-south Chile, which are key to improving its wildfire resilience. Our work contextualizes the reality of wildfires in central-south Chile and directly contributes to mitigating this growing concern by critically examining successful wildfire resilience strategies from comparable fire-prone regions, complementing ongoing local efforts and offering a practical guide for stakeholders in wildfire management and prevention, with particular relevance to central-south Chile and other regions with similar characteristics."
For more information on this research see: Improving Wildfire Resilience in the Mediterranean Central-South Regions of Chile. Fire, 2025,8(6):212. (Fire - https://www.mdpi.com/journal/fire). The publisher for Fire is MDPI AG.
A free version of this journal article is available at https://doi.org/10.3390/fire8060212.
Our news editors report that more information may be obtained by contacting Fernando Veloso, Departamento de Quimica Ambiental, Facultad de Ciencias, Universidad Catolica de la Santisima Concepcion, Concepcion 4030000, Chile. Additional authors for this research include Pablo Souza-Alonso, Gustavo Saiz.
Keywords for this news article include: Universidad Catolica de la Santisima Concepcion, Concepcion, Chile, South America, Investment and Finance, Physics.
Our reports deliver fact-based news of research and discoveries from around the world. Copyright 2025, NewsRx LLC
